pros: You can have a job that goes on a resume.
cons:
- Work life balance is hard: 

A. You are told that 8 hours is good enough and you won't have to work overtime, it's a lie. 

B. More often than not, you are working 10 hour days and weekends included to finish projects poorly designed.

- Leadership not in-sync with teams or staff: 

A. Leadership in an org, across the board, does not understand or know what the projects are or what they do - they only care about saying they have projects under their belt as a 'leader' to take credit for it. 

B. You will often see leadership who have no technical knowledge - dictating technical projects, time and again this is detrimental to the project itself.

C. Ambitious project timelines with no experience on the subject matter or time to conduct the project.

D. Resources for projects are slim or none, therefore, projects will be made by non-technical people trying to learn technical skillsets. The project quality is poor and leadership does not care - as long as they can say they have something to show.

E. Bottomline or cost savings is everything to impress their leadership, outsourcing is a means to show growth and save money (jobs get eliminated quickly).

F. Accountability among management and leadership is non-existent, individual contributors will be blamed for a manager's incompetence.

G. If you have original ideas or concepts, keep these to yourself - you will only end up regretting the fact that you thought of it and someone else takes credit for it.

F. Expertise are not valued: Get ready for seeing a Science Phd being told off by someone will a liberal arts bachelor's degree.

G. Team transferring is a good way to stall for time, working under similar conditions with other members.

1. Do not tell your manager you are transferring until the last minute. You will get pipped (performance improvement plan), if you try to transfer teams by telling your manager early on. There are many stories of this, so do some research.

job_title: Human Resources Manager in San Jose, San Jose
pros: You have the liberty of doing projects, and getting ideas across if you have a spectacular drive. Managers tend to delegate and give big responsibility if you show you are good at delivering with great standards, this will give you the freedom to own a project or do something meaningful. You will never be bored, you can move from departments or positions, there are countless possibilities. Facilities are beautiful and usually, free popcorn is available. Many activities are done every week sometimes and this might be a plus for some.
cons: The human side of issues are frowned upon, and usually not taken care of. One small event in your personal life can hinder your career, or make your manager view you as the weaker link. Usually, its a 24/7 culture, no vacations, no holidays, no weekends to yourself, even though "work-life balance" is encouraged this will depend on your direct manager, but in general terms, upper management will view you as a weaker link if you are not 24/7 committed. The performance review is done every year is very harsh, and not well thought off, they will cut the percentage of people they need to cut no matter what, and feedback is very unclear and unfrequent, so you can't really work on your weaknesses because usually, you do not know where the bar is and if you know its unreachable.

review_title: Most Toxic and Dangerous Work Environment I Have Ever Witnessed
pros: Minimal benefits and pay. Bananas during PEAK sometimes.
cons:
Highest injury rates at the robotic FC's, in the entire USA. Toxic management and HR. Mandatory overtime. Harsh discipline system, based mostly around productivity rates and "Time Off Task." Very high turnover rate. High probability of being inured. Blatant favoritism for promotions. Subtle retaliation for speaking out against policy violations by management or the company, and no team building and zero gratitude towards the hard working employees. You will not be given any positive affirmation. 

If you make a quality error under such harsh production conditions and pace, or fail to make rate, or they make a mistake on putting you in the correct "bucket" for a direct function, then you will be written up, and/or terminated.

job_title: Program Manager II in Munich, Bavaria
pros:
+ Company culture (inclusion, diversity, regular feedback mechanisms, ...) 
+ Co-workers (if the bar in the team is high, you can learn a lot from each other)
+ You can move laterally to plenty of roles, even your professional/academic background does not match the offer. Allows you to reinvent yourself.
+ Easy to transfer internationally 
+ Once you understand how the company works, it is relatively easy to get promoted
cons:
- Typically everyone is under-hired in terms of internal leveling
- Operational processes, no matter the seniority of the role
- In EU salary is low vs. comparable competitors
- Unless you get promoted, salary barely increases year over year
- Internal politics might affect promotions
- Almost everyone works overtime, which creates an unveiled pressure to work extra hours (which are not remunerated)
- In certain teams, mgmt. changes too often, which of course makes difficult that the team gets results, that people gets developed, etc.

job_title: Software Development Engineer I in Herndon, VA
pros: You are given enormous, perhaps insurmountable, responsibilities as a new grad. You could be running an AWS service with just a handful of other people who have not much more tenure than yourself. It's incredibly uncomfortable, but it forces you to learn a lot. If you can survive here for 2+ years, abundant great software engineering opportunities await you in your career. The compensation is also pretty great for a new grad from college
cons: Sure there is lots of room to learn and grow, but seriously consider the cost. You are looking down the barrel of a brutal workplace here. Sure, the compensation is good, but from day 1 you are pitted against your peers, obliterating any sense of a team dynamic. You are either at the bottom of the stack and get pushed out of the company or you climb over your peers to ensure your survival. I have certainly become a worse person since working here. You will be siloed into working on enormous codebases filled with unmaintainable garbage written in byzantine ways. Your team will likely not help you since everybody is looking after themself. Your team will likely be understaffed and overburdened by operational issues. When you go on-call, be prepared to be woken up in the middle of the night most days of the week and break your circadian rhythm every few weeks. Be ready to be nickeled-and-dimed by company benefits: your stocks won't vest when you take paternal leave, and your 401k match only vests after 3 years. All of this is malicious. Amazon does not believe in work-life balance. There is only "work-life-harmony". Be prepared to have leadership principles used as some awkward dogmatic force to exploit your labor. You will soon realize these leadership principles are so broad in their framework as to allow any manager to push you in whatever real business goal meets their demands. For example, how do you deliver results *and* insist on the highest standards? Frugality is merely an excuse to deprive employees of benefits and make sure Daddy Bezos can afford his space trip. Disagree and commit and are right a lot are a veneer for managers to be terrible to their underlings. Humanity cannot survive under the conditions present in the Amazon workplace.

The work itself gets really monotonous and tiring . You do the same thing almost every day and you can get stuck with roles you don't really like.
Most of the people I worked with here are good, but there were times when we had some guys on our shift who were just annoying and mean.
Pay is low. You're just a wage slave. Used to be even lower when I first joined.
Work can get loud. Wear ear protection.

Able to kind of control schedule as long as you get your work done

Vacation rolls over
cons:
People can be really cutthroat and out for themselves; lots of frienamies

Work load is unbearable; there is no such thing as work life balance

Too many meetings

If you're really good you just keep getting more responsibilities piled on you but can't offload anything

Prepping a backup is such a hassle it's better not to take vacation

Promotion process is time consuming

pros: Competitive starting pay for AAs. Career advancement and benefits After the Tier 3 PA position is wonderful! Senior management is truly inspirational (at my warehouse).
cons: KPIs force managers to treat all AAs the same. The elderly is expected to keep up with younger folks and injuries are daily or weekly occurrences. Badge scans are tracked so that AAs are first given a warning and then a write up if they spend more than 10 minutes away from their station "Arsaw". The arsaw is about 6x10 ft and is surrounded by metal railing/ bars. Employees report feeling "imprisoned" and in fear of going to the bathroom because of disciplinary action. I have seen mental conditions develop or worsen because of workplace anxiety. Process assistants are underpaid given the required floor responsibilities ($16 per hr)

ISMs (imagine them as COO to your CEO) are increasingly outsourced offshore meaning VMs take on additional responsibility.

Opportunity-wise, retail is increasingly a dead-end job without a ton of great opportunities at L7+ level. Externally, no great FAANG laterals are available out of this role. Other companies that value the skillset (Wayfair, Coupang, Chewy) have Amazon's poor culture but without the comp. Or they are located in Minnesota or Arkansas.

pros:
- Three-days off
- A regular schedule, where you have a set time that you punch in, and out, at each day you work; if there are extra hours/days involved, it occurs in the Peak and Prime seasons, and they give you plenty of advance notice
- Full benefits right from day one
- Paid personal time and vacation time
cons:
- Uncertainty as to what job/task you may be assigned to within your department from day to day (e.g. You may be a fulfillment associate working in the Pack Singles' department, but may be working on a SmartPac machine one day, on the Smalls line another day, the Mediums line on a separate day, the Large lines on another day, working as a Water Spider to deliver boxes to workstations and retrieve totes on other occasions, helping operate the SLAM line on a different day, assisting in the Transship area on a separate day or being sent to the Ship Docks to help load trucks on another day. Sometimes, employees may be bounced between several of these areas on a single day.)
- Only 2 half-hour breaks (one of which is your lunch) on a 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. shift, for example
- Variables that can be encountered that management does not factor into employees' rates per hour (e.g. re-loading tape on packing machines, re-loading SP00 labels on SP00 machines, re-loading SmartPac reels on SmartPac machines, re-loading labels on SmartPac machines, etc.)

job_title: Seasonal Warehouse Associate in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Nice solid pay for someone new to full time jobs. Coworkers and management were incredibly nice people. All of the horrible things you hear about Amazon warehouses aren’t true.
cons:
HR doesn’t view you as a human being. Amazon has an attendance point system that leaves no room for mercy. If you think “I’ll eat the half a point for being an hour late.” Don’t. If something happens and you can’t make it in for x amount of time, you’ll very quickly accrue the 6 point ‘maximum’. Once you hit that 6 point max, they “review your case.” But that’s just a formality. Amazon knows you’re replaceable, so they replace you. You might have incredible coworkers and management, but you’re just another number to anyone beyond that.

This job is incredibly monotonous. You spend your entire day doing one job. I wasn’t sure where to put this, because some people are into monotony, but I’m not.

job_title: Associate Corporate Counsel in Seattle, WA
pros: There are no slide decks. People hop to it and catch on quick. The way decisions get made inspires a lot of confidence. There's no more exciting place to be. At Amazon, it feels like you're on the right side of history in the making.
cons: At a large decentralized org, things can move very rapidly. If you're not on top of your stuff, it can quickly get away from you, which can feel scary if you're unprepared. The onus is on every lawyer to own their internal clients' matters in a very practicable way, know the business better than the business people, grokk risks, and give actionable advice. Your counsel has to be easy to understand and make options and recommended next steps crisp. There's no room for "legalese" here. If you're accustomed to writing long memos with pages and pages of edifying analysis, it's going to be a cold splash of water as you adapt to Amazon's writing culture. We wear hoodies like everyone else, but Amazon is otherwise a "peculiar" place. People either love it or hate it.

review_title: Amazon EARNED this review from me. Work for Amazon, and you will finally love your work
pros: I feel so good. I feel so good at work. I leave as happy as I came in. When I have a constructive conversation with my associates I feel like I'm respectful, and firm because of the patience, and training they allow their managers to have. Not every workplace does this. Not everywhere trains it's managers to treat those under then with respect. Not every workplace puts the welfare of all of their employees first. I do believe whole-heartedly that this is what sets Amazon apart.  I have the best manager I have had in my lifetime in the workforce, and practically everyone you ask for assistance is willing to help, and mentor you. When they say "work hard, have fun, make history", let me tell you they mean it. Everyday my body hurts more than it has in a long time, but I always leave with a smile, and wake up ready to go back to work. I made the decision, a few months ago, to change my career path, and I have never been happier working somewhere. I love Amazon, and I never want to work anywhere else.
cons: The long hours may not be for everyone. They physicality of it may not be for everyone. If you cannot sit at work, it IS for you.

pros: Decent opportunity to move up quick, if you can get along with people (managment), and are a hard worker. Decent hours, if you are a hard worker.
cons: Terrible, I mean awful promotion system and running of operations. The reason I say it's bad is because they put people in positions they aren't ready for emotionally. Crack under stress easy causing for a very difficult working environment.

job_title: Principal Technical Program Manager in Seattle, WA
pros:
- Amazing experience to witness the scale at which Amazon works
- Leadership principles are not just on the paper, you live them day in day out
- Dynamic, fast paced and innovative
cons:
- Some teams have become beauraucratic, which is unlike Amazon's Day1 culture
- golden handcuffs - for the hard work you did in the past 6 months, you are given future compensation in the next 2-3 years, so you have to stick along with the company for longer
- vesting every 6 months is a drag
- frugality means no free lunches or freebies.
